text: okay uh so thank you very much for coming along this morning uh my name is Gary Park uh my contact details are up
there if you have any questions uh feel free to reach out uh I'm here to talk to you about a a tool uh build
orchestration tool called cake uh and my aim today is to help answer some of the questions surrounding uh what is cake uh
why you would use it uh and also uh provide some demos at the end as to how you can actually use cake uh to achieve
that crossplatform uh build automation that a lot of us are now wanting to achieve um with the Advent of things
like net core and uh platforms and environments uh such as Mac and OSX that we want to want to Target so the first
question uh that we really want to answer is what is cake so first up for
for those of you who have come here expecting actual cake I apologize there is no cake um trust me when I say you
wouldn't want any cake that was baked by me okay um what we are here to talk about instead is this cake uh so first and for
first and foremost uh cake is a open source uh project it's been around since
2014 it's hosted on GitHub uh it was started by uh a Swedish colleague of mine called uh Patrick senson uh and
then it was later joined by another uh Swedish colleague called U Matas Carlson
I then joined the project uh so yeah full disclosure I am a member of the uh cake contribution team if there is
anything wrong with cake it's probably my fault now so feel free to to pick me up on that uh I I joined uh the tail end
of 2015 um it's a reasonably small project but it is growing in popularity um we
have almost uh 400 poll requests into the project with 60 different
contributors as well as over uh now 40 uh third party addins for the Kake EOS
system and I'll come to that in a bit what that actually means uh we're happy to say that as of today we've got about 55,000 downloads on U get so again we're
happy that it's a evolving project and people are taking an interest in it so try and answer the question about
what is cake uh this is this is the definition from the uh the cake build. net website that I encourage you to go
and have a look at so what we're trying to say is it's a crossplatform build automation system with a c DSL uh to do
things like the the compiling of code the copying of folders and so on but at the end of the day what what does that
actually mean um what we mean by that is that cake is an exe it's just an
executable that you would run uh as part of your build process and it will take as an input um a build. cake file uh and
that build. cake file will have the definition of what your build is uh it's a script processing engine uh that uses
Roslin Andor the mono compiler under the hood to take that script compile it down
into uh an executable piece of code and then I'll run that against the the the platform that you're running on the
reason that we have uh both Roslin and the mono compiler just now is just to allow that uh opens a that crossplatform
uh utilization uh at some point we will be switching to uh just Roslin once the
underlying uh rosin scripting engine become fully crossplatform we'll be switching to that in favor of of using
mono but that's that's a step down the line in terms of the road map so before I go too much further into
before I go too much further into uh what that actually means and and what cake actually is what I want to make
sure is that we're all talking about the same thing in terms of what is a build um so for me a typical build workflow
starts like this we have we have a build we want to uh we want to compile something whether that's out of Visual
Studio whether that's out of uh uh mono develop whether that's out of some other IDE we have something that we want to
build uh in order to do the build you might have something like a pack package restore step if you're doing uh if you
have new get packages within your solution you have to first restore them as part of the build in order for the build to succeed because you've taken
those dependencies uh on top of that you might want to run unit tests because as
everyone knows there should be unit tests in a project um not everyone has them but that's the ideal is you have some unit tests to go with your
project in order to complete the build you might have something like a clean step uh clean step basically just tidies
up the underlying folder structure to remove any uh artifacts as part of the build process because the last thing you
want is a build succeeding only because the last one succeeded uh so you have a clean
step um on top of that you might have some test coverage because what's the point in running tests if you're not
actually looking at the results of those tests and making sure that you're either improving or or or things are getting
worse then if you are um depending on what kind of developer you are if you're
like me you want to run some sort of Stack analysis on your code to make sure that um everything is meeting the
standards of your project team so you might use tools like style cop uh or dupinder FX cop uh or in inspect code um
those are all utilities that will basically look at your code base uh make sure that all the uh line endings are
the same that you're not doing any things that you shouldn't be uh and so on and you might have a package step so
what's the point in building something if you're not actually going to make it available for consumption uh
elsewhere and then there might be a final step which is the publish so that's to take the output of uh the
build whether it's an MSI whether it's a new get package uh whatever your output is uh you might want to push that
somewhere so that other people can consume it especially if it's a a paid for product you want to make sure that it gets there so what I'm hopefully
describing there is something that is um common to everyone it's a fairly typical workflow obviously your steps might
differ uh but what I'm going to show here is uh hopefully that cake can uh help you uh to fulfill that workflow and
a common way cuz what Cake's going to do with once we get into the the iner of
cake what Cake's going to do is is it's going to create uh what's known as a directed a cyclical graph of all of
those tasks and it'll make sure that as part of the build process each of those tasks is run at least once as part of
the build okay so with that in mind uh just a
quick brief overview of what cake actually is and what it does um so cake as I said is an ex
that exe takes as its input this build. cake file I'll show you some examples of what the build. cake file is and what it
means as we go through this in addition to the build. cake file
uh cake uh accepts a number of arguments uh into uh into the the raw cake. exe as
well as via environment variables Andor uh a configuration file that you can
actually specify within uh your your repository as well what that allows you to do is fully customize how cake is
going to work uh once you've got both the the cake file and the arguments being passed in
as part of your build script you have the option of uh using uh what we call uh pre-processor directives what they
allow you to do is to add any tools or addins into your bill workflow because
as I mentioned before uh if you're using something like uh inspect code you need to get that uh tool from somewhere uh we
don't recommend that you put those tools directly into your Source control repository because one makes your Source
control repository big um and you don't need to you can get it from elsewhere um so you can use the pre-processor
directives uh to pull those from some Source on the internet uh and and down
and and make it part of your build in addition uh because it's just C if you
want to to reference just a dll or a newg get package um to consume the uh
the ability for instance for let's say you wanted to use something like json.net you wanted to parse some Json
as part of your build process you can add of a direct a direct reference to the Newton soft dll and then within your
cake file you can just write the normal C that you would for paring that Json uh and using it as part of the build
process so once Cake's got all of those things what it's going to do is it's going to spit that out to uh either
Roslin or the the mono compiler it's going to take that script and it's going to make an executable piece of code out
of it uh obviously at that point if there are any uh syntax errors or any problems with the the script it's going
to fail it's it's a compilation step so it will fail as part of the build um but
you'll get notified of that just in the standard way uh with a a stack Trace uh and some uh pointers as to how to how to
how to correct that once all that's done it then actually executes the build and the
output of that build is literally anything that you can think of so whether it's as I said it's an exe
whether it's an MSI whether it's a new get package whether it's uh a deployment to uh Azure to Amazon literally anything
can be done as part of this build process so the world is your oyster so um I can't stress enough that um The
Familiar familiarity that you might have in C also extends directly into the the build. KCK file so whatever you can do
in C you can do within the the the build script as well okay so the next question that you might
be asking is well you you you've spoken about all these tools and what you can do within the build process so what
tools can actually be used with kick and I like to show this in this form so the
the items that are appearing here in Black are the black text are all of the tools that we have available within uh
core cake so as soon as you have a reference to cake you have you have the ability to use all of those tools the
ones that are showing up in blue are ones that have been submitted uh via our
community members so they've come as direct uh uh addins to the
project uh that's actually where I got started in the project I'm also a contributor to a
uh an open source organization called um git tools that have tools like Git Version and git release manager um I saw
that cake as a product didn't have the ability to run those tools so I use the initially I started using the uh
extension points within cake to uh have those as third party addins into the product but they've some subsequently
got merged into the core product as well so what we've got in here is the ability to do things like we basically cover all
the unit testing projects or and and ability to run test coverage we also have uh if you if you if you notice in
there we have things like slack and getter because as part of the build process you need to know when something's gone wrong and with the with
the the the explosion and the vi of slack and things like getter for communication channels you can post a
message directly into a slack Channel or a getter room uh to to notify people that something's going wrong with the
build okay so although there's a lot up there hopefully you'll see that there are uh some that are you're already
using today and you'll immediately be able to start using within cake and on top of that as I said if there's
something that's not in there that you actually require the extension points within cake make it really simple to to
add that in so the next question that you might be asking yourselves is okay but why do
I need it okay so what I want to emphasize here is that for me personally
cake is all about the uh familiarization with C but on top of that it's the
ability to have a build system that is both maintainable and consistent across those different environments so what I
mean by that is if you're just in visual studio and you're doing the control shift B to uh build the solution and
that's your workflow then that's great the problem stems from the fact that if you go on holiday and someone else tries
has to take over the project and it doesn't build on their machine because they don't have an SDK installed or they
don't have a tool installed then the build fails then that's where the communication channels break down so
having something like cake uh which allows the build to be orchestrated in such a way that it can run on any
machine uh it takes that uh concern or that problem away by uh making it or
kind of forcing you down the path of making it work on every machine but again the you're it's just in C and
that's really the big draw for it uh the other part of the process is as we mentioned is that within visual studio
if you're just doing a build within Visual Studio you might use you might be using a test Runner like resharper or end crunch to run the the the the the
tests but again you want to take that out of uh you want to take that out of
uh Visual Studio you want to have that being uh common for everyone uh to the point that you could actually hopefully
run the build uh on a machine that doesn't have Visual Studio installed you want to be able to run the build uh just
with the basic sdks and the tools installed uh rather than that dependency on all of those
property and probably the final most important part is that we want to eliminate the um the
problems with human error we all make mistakes but by putting it into uh a scripted uh process then you're allowing
the computer to take over at that point you're not worried about oh did Bob remember to do this step when you did the build or the bill remember to do
this step it's all it's becomes a documented part of your process because it's part of your Source control
repository so hopefully that ansers the question on why do we need it the other kind of questions I want to
answer today is are what are the core philosophies of cake because cake as a product has a number of ideas about what
the build process should look like but we also don't want to force those upon you uh we want cake we can make
suggestions but cake is flexible enough to allow you to run the build however you want but one of thee some of the
core philosophies of cake are it should be non-intrusive so some of the other build processes or build pipeline uh
pipelines that you might have used require modification to things like your CS Pro files in order for it to to to to
work uh cake is fully non-intrusive and but what I mean by that is it's a standalone uh bill. cake file that uh
will reside uh beside your code and that's it it doesn't require uh any
other uh tie into the system so what that means is or what we like to say is you can start using cake without telling
your project manager about it and once he's seen the power of what power cake can give you you can then just slot it in because you haven't actually affected
any of the rest of your process uh the other thing we like to say is it should just work um we have tie-ins and
aliases for uh all of the most common tools they're being run on a number of different build systems now um for
instance we use cake to build cake um so we like to uh we like to do that because
we can then obviously uh see any problems that are creeping through so if things aren't working uh there's
something wrong with cake obviously but we we test it to an extent uh every time we do a release so we hope it just works
we also want cake to be highly configurable so what we mean by that is uh as part of uh the build process when
you need to change something uh you can do that it's highly configurable and with the most recent release of cake
it's actually completely modularize now as well so that if there's something within cake uh that you don't like you
can uh you can rip that out and replace it with your own uh specific implementation
of uh that particular part of cake the other core tenant that we like
to uh suggest to people is that there should be no binaries checked into Source control simply putop um they're
not required you want to have them coming from somewhere else and that goes for cake as well and what we'll come on to as part of the demonstration is we'll
show how we uh as a product suggest that you bring actual cake the cake. exe into
your pipeline as I said before we want it to be easy to implement your own tools and
I I I can vouch for that because that's where I started and the final tenant is that we
we want the build to look and behave the same regardless of what operating system you're working on or what environment
you're running on and the the the most easiest way to to show that is by
showing you this so that is uh on our GitHub reports within the read me. text
uh we build cake with cake on eight different CI servers and we run it on
across three different operating systems so you might think that that's a little bit excessive
but there are certain parts of the tooling that behave differently uh depending on what CI server that is
running on what continuous integration server it's running on for instance uh something like the um the unit testing
framework n unit it knows that it might be running on something like team City so it automatically pushes uh test
results into the the team C system via uh what it calls service messages so we like to make sure that cake when it's
utilizing these tools uh continues to function as we as we want it to uh the
the eagle eyed amongst you might notice that the Travis build was failing when I took that screenshot uh that was to do

to address is can I just use fake or make or cake or mamis build

simple answer is yes I'm not going to say I'm not going to stand up here and tell you that you have to use cake if

to use cake um but I can't force you to but what what I like to say here is that
we've heard through our community members and various uh uh conversations that we've had is that there's this
concept of well if you're doing a c development project then using uh the build system to uh learn another
language is a good way to do it so if you wanted to pick up Powershell for instance you might want to use saki or
if you wanted to pick up F then you might want to use fake as as the build system because then you're kind of being forced into that different language and
uh it's a good way of learning and I I fully agree with that to an extent the the extent is when that build
fails you then have to do a mental mind switch into that other language to fix it and the the problem I I've seen even
with my own company is that you become that one person who knows how to make the build work because you're the one
who put it in place uh using something like fit cake uh makes sense if you're
doing a c project because you don't then have that mental mind switch between the two languages you simply then have
you're you're going a direct Port from one language to the other and you're fixing the same problems so what I would
say is if you're doing a Powershell project use saki if you're doing an F project then use fake but if you're
using a a a a C project then use something like cake or bow or one of the other C based systems that are out there
